Annual dues in the Association, including a subscription to our monthly
Newsletter and the above mentioned materials, are based on rated trans¬
mitter power, as follows:
Class A - 5 kv and over - $50.00
Class B - 1 - U.9 kw - 25.00
Class C - Less than 1 kw - 15.00
In addition to the above, member stations enjoy the benefits of our Place¬
ment Service, legal counsel, help in meeting day-to-day problems, the oppor¬
tunity to meet, in seminars, conferences and conventions, with other educa¬
tional broadcasters to consider mutual problems, and, for the payment of
an additional assessment fee, the use of our tape network.
The NAEB Network, which distributes over I4OO hours of programming, via
tape recording, per year, is open only to members of the Association.
Through the Network you have an opportunity to broadcast some of the best
educational programs from all over the country as well as a chance to have
some of your better programs receive wider distribution. In addition,
being able to rely on the Network for eight or more hours of programming
per week permits your staff to spend more time on the development of out¬
standing programs.
By recent action of the NAEB Executive Committee, new members are allowed
to join the Network without paying the full assessment fee. A graduated
scale has been set up whereby new stations do not pay the full fee until
the third year. Annual Network assessments are based on the same power
classifications as membership:

In addition, member stations must pay postage both ways on tapes shipped
to and from the Network. For a station in your area this would amount
to approximately -27.50 a year if you availed yourself of all the pro¬
grams made available ty the Network. (There is a strong possibility that
there will soon be Congressional action to lower rates for educational re¬
cordings, which would make postage payments considerably lower). Even with
the postage charges you see that the cost per hour of programming (for I4.OO
hours, or more) is very low.
In addition to the regular Network service described above (a sample Net¬
work offering is included in the material being sent separately), we make
available in?-school programs to those stations who do in-school broadcast¬
ing. For this service a station pays an additional fee of one-fourth of
